results.title: I Know they can get me pregnant (TEFC)
results.brief_description: Would-be mothers, patients at the In-Vitro Fertilisation Clinic at the Royal North Shore Hospital, describe their feelings. This program provides material for discussion on such topics as the role of the social worker, the ethics of test-tube babies and the care of patients.

results.title: I know an old lady who swallowed a fly
results.creator_credit: ONF | NFB, Colin Low, Tom Daly and Derek Lamb
results.brief_description: A nonsense song, sung by Burl Ives and given unrestrained interpretation by the cartoonist. Of course, by the time the song ends the old lady has swallowed much more than a fly. Written by Canadian folksinger Alan Mills. (Awards: Santa Barbara; Chicago; Gottwaldov)

results.title: I Know a secret (K)
results.creator_credit: Atlantis Films, Michael Macmillan, Seaton McLean, Janice Platt and Bruce Pittman
results.brief_description: A film adaptation of a short story by Lucy Maud Montgomery set during the late 1930s. The story is about a young girl called Jane Lawrence, and some children she becomes acquainted with after she moves to the country with her mother to live.

results.title: I keep remembering Ita (TEFC)
results.brief_description: A videotape and study guide about the positive role of older people in the community. It presents three distinct personal portraits of older women and three different approaches to growing older. Each portrait shows older people taking charge of their lives. The women portrayed have a positive attitude to themselves and their community. Study guide available.

The women portrayed have a positive attitude to themselves and their community. Study guide available.

results.title: I Keep Remembering Ita (Captioned)
results.brief_description: A video about the positive role of older people in the community. Through three distinctive personal portraits of older women, and their approach to growing older we see how all three take charge of their lives and have a positive attitude to themselves and their community.

results.title: I keep remembering Ita
results.creator_credit: Oceania Media Network and Anne Bourke
results.brief_description: Many older people can play an important role in our community because of their skills, knowledge and experience. However, the media often portray older people as a hidden group. Politically they very often remain the victims despite changing attitudes. “I Keep Remembering Ita” presents three distinctive personal portraits of older women with three different approaches to growing older. Each portrait shows older people taking charge of their lives with the help of a positive mental attitude towards themselves and their community.

results.title: I just work here
results.creator_credit: Roundtable Productions and Leon S. Gold
results.brief_description: Shows how customer service can be improved when the person providing the service makes an extra effort to understand the customer’s point of view and does not rigidly adhere to the rules.

results.title: I Is for important
results.brief_description: The film covers examples of sex role stereotyping in social interaction and emotional expression in schools. The scenes include sex role bias in disciplinary actions and student task assignments and children’s resistance to role reversal in kindergarten play.

results.title: I Hung back, held fire, danced and lied
results.material_description: Single channel moving image, black and white and colour and audio
results.brief_description: In I hung back, held fire, danced and lied, Kalin confronts loss, intimacy and estrangement. This visually arresting piece is constructed of Super-8 fragments that document familiar and foreign spaces, lovers and strangers. Rapidly intercut with these images are brief glimpses of names of individuals who have died from AIDS — some famous, others not so well known — that further notions of anonymity and immortality. Kalin’s imagery serves as an ‘imprint’ of the living world, preserving for an unknown viewer personal experiences that have already fled. Kalin concludes with a quote from The Black Boy Looks on the White Boy by James Baldwin: “I hung back, held fire, dance and lied. I was not going to come crawling out of my ruined house, all bloody, no, baby, sing no sad songs for me.
results.title_for_label: I Hung back, held fire, danced and lied
